meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>power</radical> of your <radical>mouth</radical> lets you <kanji>add</kanji> words together to form a sentence. Marvel at the mighty additive power your mouth holds! You add words together in an amazing fashion!

On the bottom of <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>root</radical>s, there’s a <radical>stamp</radical> that tells you the <kanji>season</kanji> in which it was cut.

Additionally, the stamp also has information on the condition of the bamboo’s <kanji>joint</kanji>s, because no one wants to buy bamboo with damaged joints!
Direct a <radical>tsunami</radical> into a <radical>canine</radical>'s <radical>mouth</radical> to <kanji>decrease</kanji> the amount of water that strikes the surrounding area.
When they migrate to a <radical>river</radical>, a group of <radical>geoducks</radical> must do so in a certain <kanji>order</kanji> and <kanji>sequence</kanji>.
If you put a <radical>roof</radical> over a <radical>valley</radical> it will change its <kanji>form</kanji>. Its <kanji>appearance</kanji> will alter completely!
To a <radical>narwhal</radical>, a <radical>towel</radical> is just normal <kanji>cloth</kanji>. They're always wet so towel cloth is all they know.
The <radical>easy</radical> radical and the <kanji>easy</kanji> kanji are the same!

Give some <radical>shellfish</radical> to a <radical>talent</radical>ed person and they'll have no problem accumulating <kanji>wealth</kanji>. People with talent can make money out of pretty much anything, so shellfish are like easy-mode.

There are <radical>flowers</radical> on your <radical>right</radical> to show that you're still <kanji>young</kanji>. Your body still works, you're happy, you have your entire life ahead of you! And everything smells like flowers.

What you <radical>say</radical> to the <radical>director</radical> is judged immediately. You're having trouble understanding this <kanji>part of speech</kanji>, so he's trying to help you. But you say it over and over and he keeps saying you're wrong.
If the <radical>sun</radical> is <radical>compare</radical>d to an <kanji>insect</kanji>, you’ll see that they're both shiny, but that the sun is much shinier than the insect.

Passed out in front of your <radical>gate</radical> lies a former <radical>leader</radical>. He's now a <radical>drunkard</radical>, but once ran a popular <kanji>clique</kanji> called the Cool Kids <kanji>Clan</kanji>. The clan has fallen apart, and he no longer has a clique to call his own.

At the edge of the <radical>cliff</radical>, two <radical>tree</radical>s mark the spot where you must <radical>stop</radical>, since any <kanji>continuation</kanji> requires a way across. The trees seem long enough to reach to the other side, but how are you going to chop them down?
The <radical>tongue</radical> radical and the <kanji>tongue</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Yee-haw!

You use a <radical>bookshelf</radical> as a <kanji>book counter</kanji>. Duh. What, are you gonna count them one by one? Okay, well maybe, but you should count them while they're nice and organized on the shelves. Otherwise counting is going to be a huge pain.
You use a <radical>roof</radical> to keep yourself <radical>dry</radical> and safe from <kanji>outer space</kanji>. Look outside, above your roof, and you'll see outer space stretching above you.

You jumped off your <radical>roof</radical> for some <radical>reason</radical> and now you're floating in <kanji>midair</kanji>! You kick your legs a bit and move your arms like you're in water, but you're still just stuck there in midair.

You'll work your <radical>soul</radical> to <radical>death</radical> if you're too <kanji>busy</kanji>. Being busy just isn't good for your soul. Take breaks. Go on vacation. Don't be so busy that you destroy yourself.
A <radical>flag</radical> <radical>loiter</radical>s in a <radical>black hole</radical>. This flag marks (in the black hole) where you left your <kanji>footwear</kanji>.
Use your <radical>mouth</radical> to take a <radical>measurement</radical> of this <kanji>group</kanji>. Just stretch your mouth out and around every single person. Get 'em all in there.

When the <radical>sun</radical> gets <radical>together</radical> with <radical>water</radical>, only <kanji>violence</kanji> can ensue. They don’t mix well together. The sun loves to fight water and water loves to fight the sun. Lots and lots of violence.

A raging <radical>tsunami</radical> rises next to the calm <radical>sun</radical>. When you try to <radical>compare</radical> these two things, it's clear that they cannot <kanji>mix</kanji>. If a tsunami is coming, it will likely get in the way of the sun.

If you stab somebody in the <radical>tongue</radical> with an <radical>umbrella</radical>, it’s sure to start a <kanji>riot</kanji> and cause <kanji>disorder</kanji>. Nobody likes to get stabbed in the tongue with an umbrella, so they’re probably going to retaliate, and before you know it, you’ve a full scale riot on your hands. Look what you’ve done.

“Don’t <radical>loiter</radical> – <radical>run</radical>, <kanji>Junior</kanji>!” said Indiana Jones Senior to Indiana Jones Junior. They’re escaping from a sticky situation and Junior was just loitering around like a fool. It’s no time to loiter, it’s time to run!

If you <radical>loiter</radical> around the <radical>sun</radical> <radical>temple</radical>, it's likely you'll <kanji>acquire</kanji> something. When you loiter around like that it looks like you're waiting for something, so if someone puts something in your hands and you just happen to acquire it, well, no one can fault you for that.

It's important to focus <radical>oneself</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> so that one can emerge <kanji>renew</kanji>ed! You can't really go outside in winter without getting cold or sick, so spend winter focusing on YOU.

You have to gather <radical>thread</radical> to <radical>sell</radical> if you want to <kanji>continue</kanji> living. You want to make a living, don't you? Make sure you continue to sell that thread every single day!
Your <radical>scooter</radical> and your <radical>car</radical> is what you always <kanji>take along</kanji> with you. Make sure they're <kanji>connect</kanji>ed well so you don't lose them!

A <radical>sheep</radical> loses its <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> so it picks them up in its <radical>mouth</radical> to take them to someone who's <kanji>morally good</kanji> enough to attach them back onto its head. Sheep don’t have hands, so the sheep had to pick the horns up off the ground with his mouth. Someone evil would just murder the sheep and steal his horns, so the sheep must find someone <kanji>good</kanji> to reaffix them.

If you put a <radical>thread</radical> in the middle of a <radical>kiss</radical>, you’re going to <kanji>entangle</kanji> it. Things can get pretty messy in a kiss, so adding a thread to the mix will definitely entangle it.
Within the <radical>bamboo</radical> grove, someone asks your <radical>reason</radical> for being there, and you explain it's to harvest bamboo to craft a <kanji>flute</kanji>.
The <radical>history</radical> radical and the <kanji>history</kanji> kanji are the same.
If you see some <radical>flowers</radical> that are <radical>dry</radical>, pull them up and you'll find a <kanji>potato</kanji>.

The <radical>dirt</radical> next to your <radical>village</radical> is where you <kanji>bury</kanji> the dead. People don't live forever, so every village has a patch of dirt specifically used for burying dead things.
